questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following nerve is a branch of lumbar plexus?
questions.explanation:
The femoral nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the posterior (dorsal) 
divisions of the ventral rami of L2–L4. 1094 
Sold by @itachibot The sciatic nerve, posterior femoral cutaneous nerve, and nerve to obturator internus are a part of 
sacral plexus.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient presents with tingling, numbness, and burning pain in the outer part of the right 
thigh. There is no motor dysfunction. What is the root value of this patient's affected nerve?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica, in which the lateral cutaneous nerve of 
the thigh is affected. The root value of this nerve is L2 and L3. It arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3 and supplies the skin of the 
anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh upto the knee. The images given below represent the root value and the area supplied by the lateral cutaneous 
nerve of the thigh. 1095 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus?
questions.explanation: The sciatic nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus. It is the largest branch of the sacral plexus.

questions.question:
Question 4: The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by which of the following 
arteries?
questions.explanation:
The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by the lateral circumflex 
femoral artery. The course of femoral nerve is given below: • Arises from posterior division of ventral rami of L2-L4 spinal segments on the posterior 
abdominal wall • Enters the femoral triangle by passing under the inguinal ligament • In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery and outside the femoral sheath • Divided into anterior and posterior branches by lateral circumflex femoral artery Note: Obturator nerve is divided into anterior and posterior divisions by obturator externus in the 
upper part and adductor brevis in the lower part.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following branches of the femoral nerve arises from its main trunk and passes 
below the inguinal ligament?
questions.explanation:
The Nerve to pectineus arises near and passes below the inguinal ligament and then runs behind 
the femoral sheath. The femoral nerve gives off the nerve to iliacus and pectineus before it divides into the anterior 
and posterior divisions. The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve. 1096 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 60-year-old woman after a trivial fall presents with pelvic fracture along with left femoral 
nerve injury. The function of all of the following muscles will be affected except:
questions.explanation:
Gracilis is supplied by the obturator nerve and not the femoral nerve. Hence, the function of 
gracilis muscle will be normal in this patient. Branches of the femoral nerve: • Before entering the thigh, the femoral nerve supplies branches to the iliacus and pectineus 
muscles • The anterior division of femoral nerves supplies the sartorius and gives sensation to 
the anteromedial aspect of the thigh by the branches medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh and 
intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh • The posterior division of the femoral nerve supplies branches to the quadriceps femoris muscles, 
knee joint and gives sensation to the medial aspect of the leg by the saphenous nerve. The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve. 1097 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient presents with a loss of extension of the knee joint. On examination, decreased 
sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh is noted. Which of the following nerve is likely 
damaged in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Loss of extension of the knee joint with decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh 
suggests damage to the femoral nerve. The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps femoris muscles which are the extensors of the knee 
joint. It provides sensory branches to the anterior and medial aspect of the thigh by medial and 
intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh. The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.

questions.question:
Question 8: 1089 
Sold by @itachibot In a patient, following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, sensation over 
the medial side of the leg was lost. The affected nerve is a branch of which of the following 
nerves?
questions.explanation:
1098 
Sold by @itachibot Loss of sensation of the medial side of the leg denotes injury to the saphenous nerve. It is a 
branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve. The saphenous nerve is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to 
the femoral artery. It then enters the adductor canal where it crosses anterior to the femoral 
artery to lie medial to it. It leaves the adductor canal by piercing the fascia lata between the 
gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. It then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the long saphenous vein and 
supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee leg and foot as far as up to the first 
metatarsophalangeal joint. The images given below show the cutaneous innervation of the lower limb. 1099 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: Obturator nerve block is performed on a patient with severe chronic hip pain. Anterior 
division of this nerve innervates all of the following muscles except:
questions.explanation:
The anterior division of the obturator nerve does not innervate the adductor magnus. It is 
supplied by the posterior division of the obturator nerve. The obturator nerve arises from the anterior division of the ventral rami of L2-L4. Near the 
obturator foramen, it divides into anterior and posterior branches. • Anterior division supplies pectineus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, and gracilis • Posterior division supplies adductor magnus, obturator externus. It also supplies adductor brevis 
if the muscle is not supplied by the anterior division The image given below shows the course of the obturator nerve.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following nerve does not innervate the muscles of the gluteal region?
questions.explanation:
The sciatic nerve does not innervate the muscles of the gluteal region. It is the largest nerve of the body and is made up of L4 to S3 spinal nerves of the sacral plexus. It 
leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis. It descends in the 
posterior thigh and divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves proximal to the knee joint. The tibial component of the sciatic nerve supplies: • Semimembranosus • Semitendinosus • Ischial part of adductor magnus • Long head of biceps femoris The common fibular component of the sciatic nerve supplies a short head of the biceps femoris. The images given below shows the course of the Sciatic nerve. 1100 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 40-year-old man comes with a history of a hip fracture which was treated surgically, four 
months ago. You observe him walking with the gait shown below. Injury to which of the 
following nerves is most likely in this patient? 1090 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of left superior gluteal nerve injury. The patient shows characteristic lurching gait/ Trendelenburg's gait (positive Trendelenburg's 
sign), which is seen in paralysis of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. These muscles 
are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the 
opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action 
results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk 
in the upright position. When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported 
(normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. 1101 
Sold by @itachibot In the given case, when the patient lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, his right 
pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right 
side is normal. Hence, the left superior gluteal nerve injury is present in this case. The image given below shows the Trendelenberg test. Note: Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.

questions.question: Question 12: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
questions.explanation:
Foot drop is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies 
the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to peroneus 
longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves. • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the 
evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace 
and lateral side of the little toe. • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the 
dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin 
between great and second toes. Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to: • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop • Loss of eversion • Loss of extension of toes • Sensory loss • Anterior and lateral side of the leg 1102 
Sold by @itachibot • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe Th image given below shows the course of common peroneal nerve.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 45-year-old man came for his cast removal after a right tibial fracture. You noted that the 
patient lifted his right leg high to take a step. On examination, the right foot was inverted and 
sensory loss was present on the whole dorsum of the right foot. Which of the following nerves 
is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The nerve affected in this patient is the common fibular nerve (common peroneal nerve). It is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami. The sciatic nerve divides into the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve. The common fibular nerve runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular 
head. It lies between the biceps femoris and lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves 
laterally around the neck of the fibula, where it is most commonly injured (e.g., due to a tight 
plaster cast). It gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves. Injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to: • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop • Loss of eversion • Loss of extension of toes • Sensory loss • Anterior and lateral side of the leg • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe The images given below show the common peroneal nerve course and the sensory area supplied. 1103 
Sold by @itachibot 1104 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Ankle reflex is preserved in common peroneal nerve palsy.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following does not share its nerve supply with the rest of the given muscles?
questions.explanation:
Peroneus longus is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve. The rest of the muscles 
mentioned above are innervated by the deep peroneal nerve. The anterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. It consists of: • Tibialis anterior • Extensor hallucis longus • Extensor digitorum longus • Peroneus tertius The lateral compartment of leg is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve. It consists of 
peroneus longus and peroneus brevis. The posterior compartment of leg is supplied by the tibial nerve. It consists of • Gastrocnemius • Soleus • Plantaris • Popliteus • Flexor hallucis longus • Flexor digitorum longus • Tibialis posterior

questions.question:
Question 15: In a patient with Morton’s neuroma, branches of which of the following nerves will get 
entrapped?
questions.explanation:
Morton’s neuroma may occur due to the entrapment of branches of the medial plantar nerve. It is the most common form of nerve entrapment in the foot. It is due to the entrapment of the 
3rd common digital nerve which is a branch of the medial plantar nerve. The medial plantar nerve can also be compressed at the Knot of Henry. It is the point where the 
tendon of flexor hallucis longus passes deep to the tendon of flexor digitorum longus to reach the 
medial side of the sole of the foot. The image given below shows the Morton's neuroma. 1105 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Baxter’s nerve is a branch of which of the following nerves?
questions.explanation:
Baxter’s nerve is a branch of the lateral plantar nerve. Clinical significance: Compression of Baxter's nerve by the deep fascia that covers abductor 
hallucis is implicated to be a possible cause of chronic heel pain and plantar fasciitis.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex?
questions.explanation:
Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the 
testicle following stroking of the medial thigh. The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches: • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve Given below are the various reflexes with their root values. Deep reflexes 
Superficial reflexes Biceps -C5, C6 
Corneal - CN V(A) - CN VII(E) - Pons Brachioradialis - C5, C6 
Conjunctival - CN V (A) - CN 
VII(E) - Pons Triceps - C6, C› 
Scapular - C5, T1 Finger flexion - C8 
Abdominal - T›-T12 Knee jerk - L3,L4 
Anal - S3, S4 Ankle -S1, S2 
Cremastric -L1, L2 1106 
Sold by @itachibot Deep reflexes 
Superficial reflexes Jaw jerk - CN V (Pons) 
Plantar - L5S1

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a branch of the femoral artery?
questions.explanation:
The deep circumflex iliac artery is a branch of the external iliac artery, not the femoral artery. The femoral artery is the continuation of the external iliac artery. It starts behind the inguinal 
ligament midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis. It descends in the thigh anteromedially in the femoral triangle and passes through the adductor 
canal. It exits the adductor canal by passing through adductor hiatus, to reach the popliteal fossa 
and becomes the popliteal artery. Branches of the femoral artery given below: • Superficial epigastric artery • Superficial circumflex iliac artery • Superficial external pudendal artery • Deep external pudendal arteries • Muscular branches • Profunda femoris artery • Descending genicular artery

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following artery does not take part in the cruciate anastomosis?
questions.explanation:
The superior gluteal artery does not contribute to the formation of cruciate anastomosis. 1107 
Sold by @itachibot Cruciate anastomosis lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by: • Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries • Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery • Ascending branch of the first perforating artery The image given below shows the anastomosis around the hip joint. Note: Traumatic insults to the lower extremity (fractures, stab wounds, or gunshot wounds) can 
result in blood loss. It is important for the clinician to understand the arterial anastomoses in the 
affected area so that bleeding can be appropriately managed and exsanguination can be avoided.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 60-year-old man presented with pain while walking after a prolonged flight travel. 
Ultrasonography revealed thrombus in the short saphenous vein. If the thrombus gets 
dislodged, it is likely to enter which of the following veins first?
questions.explanation:
A thrombus in the short saphenous vein may get dislodged and enter the popliteal vein. The 
embolus may further travel into the right heart and eventually may cause a pulmonary embolism. The short saphenous vein is the continuation of the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch. It 
passes behind the lateral malleolus and drains into the popliteal vein in the popliteal fossa. The 
popliteal vein continues as the femoral vein proximal to the knee. The image given below shows the venous drainage of the lower limb. 1108 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: What are above knee perforators known as?
questions.explanation:
Above knee perforators are known as Dodd's veins. Perforator veins connect the deep and superficial venous systems, allowing the passage of blood in 
between them. Following are the named perforators of the lower limb: • Proximal thigh level perforators - Hunter perforator veins • Distal thigh perforators - Dodd perforator veins • Below the knee perforators - Boyd perforator veins • Calf level perforators - Cockett perforator veins 1109 
Sold by @itachibot Important Structures of Lower Limb
